summary: This is an email chain from August 11, 2019, discussing the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). It covers the status of evidence collection (video, logs, phone records), discrepancies in accounts of Epstein's last phone call, the legal theory for potential charges against guards, and coordination between the FBI, OIG, and prosecutors.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate at the center of the investigation; the email discusses the circumstances around his death in custody at MCC.

events.title: Epstein's Death in Custody
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). The email chain discusses the subsequent investigation into the circumstances, including guard conduct and evidence collection.

events.title: Epstein's Autopsy
events.description: The defense arranged for a pathologist to be present at Epstein's autopsy, which was scheduled to begin at 9 AM.

keyFacts: Epstein was not on suicide watch at the time of his death (he had only been on suicide watch from July 23-29, 2019) and was not required to have a cellmate.
The FBI seized 18 hard drives of video from the MCC for analysis, though a camera pointed at the SHU hallway was reportedly not functioning as of the Thursday before Epstein's death.

Investigators received a proffer from Epstein's lawyer regarding his last phone call, in which he did not indicate suicidal intent but said 'they are trying to keep me safe' and discussed his case taking longer.
There was a discrepancy between the lawyer's claim of a 20-minute last call and BOP records indicating a 10-second call; investigators were pulling toll records to investigate.

Investigators were considering a charge under 18 U.S.C. ยง 1519 (destruction/falsification of records) against guards based on admissions they did not perform required rounds and falsified log sheets.
